title: In the electromagnetic spectrum, what is the largest wavelength possible, and what is the smallest? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the electromagnetic spectrum, what is the largest wavelength possible, and what is the smallest? Well, theoretically, a photon could be extremely low energy and have a wavelength measured in anywhere from light years to the width of the observable universe. And a sufficiently high energy photon could have a wavelength somewhere near the Planck length. However, you’re only going to see super-long wavelengths for sources that have been highly red-shifted, either due to receding velocity from the universe expanding or from climbing out of a black hole’s gravity well. Meanwhile, at the high-energy end, it’s unlikely that there’s any realistic way to create a Planck length wavelength photon near [math]10^{-44}[/math] meters, as the energy requirement is insanely high. Getting the energy isn’t the problem - it’s packing it all into one photon rather than 2 photons with half the energy, or 45 photons with 1/45th the energy, etc. There’s also weirdness because at that energy density, you have to start worrying about the gravitational field generated by the energy. Those are theoretical limits, of course, In practice we’ve only actually detected some particularly exuberant gamma rays with a wavelength of [math]10^{-19}[/math] meters , and extreme low frequency radio-range photons with wavelengths around 100,000 km.
